title: "Don’t communicate by sharing memory; share memory by communicating."
body:
If you've been around the Go language long enough, then you must have come across the famous Go proverb "Don’t communicate by sharing memory; share memory by communicating." at some point in time. And if you haven't then now you have! :p

At first glance it looks like the proverb is composed of 2 different goals. i.e

Goal 1: Communication

Goal 2: Share Memory

To me, that sounded like - "Don't eat an apple; drive a car." Two unrelated sentences stringed together to form advice!

I found this confusing and started up a conversation about it with my colleagues at work and it was after listening to everyone's interpretation that I gained a clear understanding of what the proverb truly means.

The proverb is meant as advice on how to communicate within the Go programming language. Therefore the sentence has only 1 goal which is communication and not 2 as I earlier thought.

Communication is the only goal

It is similar to saying - "Don't live to work; work to live". Where the only goal is to live or teach one how to live

What I expected the sentence to be was something along the lines of: "Don't communicate by sharing memory; instead communicate by ....". Now thinking of it, I guess that would have been too easy and boring. Whoever wrote that proverb wanted us to think a bit harder of it's meaning

If you found this or still find this confusing, share your thoughts and let's talk :)
